formattedAddress: 928 Amsterdam Ave, New York, NY 10025, USA
adrFormatAddress: 928 Amsterdam Ave, New York, NY 10025, USA

originalText.text: Miss Saigon has a sleek interior with bright banquette seating. For lunch, I ordered the  hot and sour soup ($5.95 plus tax) which had nice fresh vegetables and herbs. However, the sweetness from the pineapple chunks masked the sour tang of the broth. They certainly did not skimp on the shrimp for the drunken noodles ($14.95 plus tax) but it could have been spicier and slightly less oily.

originalText.text: Excellent service and a relaxed ambience. Normally, shrimp soup is the go to but tried the lemongrass chicken and was very pleased.

text.text: Excellent service and a relaxed ambience. Normally, shrimp soup is the go to but tried the lemongrass chicken and was very pleased.

originalText.text:
This restaurant delivers in all aspects of quality. Food, service, and experience.

The fried spring rolls are out of this world. Both the chicken and pork bahnmi sandwiches are toasted, and the mayo is delightful. The glaze is amazing and cooked to perfection. The ox tail broth pho is amazing!

The service is amazing! Always providing ample napkins and topping up our water. I love.

Thank you. Will come again and advertise for you.

Thank you. Will come again and advertise for you.

originalText.text: I was super excited to see a new Vietnamese spot in this neighborhood (it’s been lacking one since Saigon Grill shuttered years ago). Sadly, this food is truly awful. Everything we ordered (there were five of us so we got a lot) seemed to have been microwaved: they all had that over-steamed, soggy texture and general tastelessness you get when you set the timer too long on your Trader Joe’s burritos. Honestly you’d be better off grabbing some of the frozen Vietnamese foods from TJs. The waitstaff was super nice and the restaurant was clean, but to survive in this eclectic area surrounded by great restaurants (delicious Indian, Ethiopian, Thai, Falafel, and Chinese are all within 1-3 blocks) you’ve gotta bring the goods.

originalText.text:
vvvvvvvery very very good food. i had only dipped in here for its quietude and burnt orange booths and wifi after a long day out alone far from home, comfortable in the Tuesday emptiness of this long-roomed restaurant. I didn’t expect such a gourmet turnout! Jesus christ!
This food is VERY good. The hot and sour shrimp soup is so fresh and bright and veggie filled and complex, and the spring rolls are ssssssssssssssso good. So crispy and dimensional and they come with the big lettuce pieces.

I also love how quiet it is in here on a Tuesday at 8, as a singular person who came in to write on their laptop, but I hope theyre busier usually. They are ten star!!!! I’m gonna bring my dad here next time he’s in the city, yknow? Like they’re that sort of reliably impressive wowowsotasty kind of place.
Plus these orange booths! Veeery coolbeautiful. I like the broad and silent tiled walls too. It must be busy here on fridays but i feel lucky to have a quiet tuesday in late september alone.
